info.title: Splunk Mission Control Automation API Reference
info.description: The Splunk Mission Control Automation API allows your team to automate their response to Mission Control incidents using Splunk SOAR playbooks. This API documentation corresponds to the actions available in the Mission Control block in the Splunk SOAR Visual Playbook Editor (VPE). To learn more about the Mission Control block, see [Use Splunk Mission Control data in Splunk SOAR (Cloud) playbooks](https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/MC/Current/Detect/Playbook) in *Investigate and Respond to Threats in Splunk Mission Control*. The following APIs are not applicable for use cases outside of the Mission Control/SOAR integration. Any other use of these or other Mission Control APIs is not supported.

stack.description: this value is assigned by the service provider, in this example `blueridge.splunkcloud.com`

requestBody.description: Request payload for a single incident.

parameters.description: The `id` (GUID) or the `display_id` of the incident.

schema.description: The ID of the incident that the newly created event belongs to.

requestBody.description: Update a Splunk Mission Control incident.

post.description: Update a Splunk Mission Control incident.
Create events in Splunk Mission Control.
Update events in Splunk Mission Control.
Set summary fields on an incident. Fields that already exist will be updated. Fields that donâ€™t exist yet will be created.
Remove summary fields. If a specified field does not exist, this action has no affect.

get.description: Retrieve an incident by the incident GUID or display ID without running a search. The response matches the data available for dispatch to automation.

parameters.description: The name of the response template.

parameters.name: phase_name
parameters.description: The name of the phase you want to retrieve the phase ID from.

get.description: Retrieve a phase ID by providing the incident ID, phase name, and response template name. The response matches the data available for dispatch to automation.

id.description: The id (GUID) of the incident.

name.description: The name of the incident.

incident_origin.description: Where the incident came from. For example, Splunk Enterprise Security, a risk-based alerting notable, or a Splunk Mission Control incident.

incident_type.description: The incident type of the incident. Incident types are used to categorize related incidents by use case or source.

disposition.description: The classification of the incident. For example, â€œTrue Positive - Suspicious Activityâ€ or â€œFalse Positive - Incorrect Analytic Logicâ€.

status.description: The status of the incident. For example, â€œNewâ€ or â€œIn Progressâ€.

assignee.description: The person or group assigned to the incident.

urgency.description: The urgency of the incident. Valid choices are informational, low, medium, high, or critical.

sensitivity.description: The sensitivity of the incident. Valid choices are White, Green, Amber, Red, or Unassigned.

pairs.description: A list of fields that describe the event.

value.description: The value of the data field. Any type is accepted: string, number, array, object, or null.

The unique ID for the response plan.

version.description: The version of the response plan.

is_default.description: Whether or not the response plan is the default plan.

source_template_id.description: The ID of the source template for this response plan.

create_time.description: The time the response plan was created.

update_time.description: The time the response plan was last updated.

name.description: The name of the response plan.

description.description: The description of the response plan.
description.example: There are many ways in which attackers can use email to gain a foothold in an organization or advance an existing campaign. This response template guides an analyst through the process of investigating and remediating several of these methods.

template_status.description: The status of the response plan. For example, â€œIn Progressâ€.

creator.description: The person who created this plan.

updated_by.description: The person who updated the plan.

id.description: The ID for the response template.

is_default.description: Whether or not the response template is the default template.

name.description: Name of the response template.

description.description: The description of the response template.
description.example: This is a response template created by a user

template_status.description: The status of the response template, for example "Published".

creator.description: The user who created this template.

updated_by.description: The user who updated this template.

create_time.description: The time when the response template was created, as an epoch time stamp.

update_time.description: The time when the response template was last updated, as an epoch time stamp.

phases.description: A list of phases in the response template.

name.description: The name of the response phase.

order.description: The order of the response phase.

create_time.description: The time when the response template was created, as an epoch time stamp.

update_time.description: The time when the response template was last updated, as an epoch time stamp.

tasks.description: A list of tasks in the response template.

name.description: The name of the task.

tag.description: The ID of the task that maps a response plan task to its original template.

order.description: The order of the task in respect to all tasks in the phase.

description.example: Create any necessary tickets or tracking documents describing the initial conditions of the suspicious email investigation. As additional information is collected or actions are taken in the following tasks and phases, update the ticket with links and relevant information to allow collaboration and tracking.

is_note_required.description: Determines whether a note is required to be created in order to complete or end the task.

start_time.description: The time when the task was started.

end_time.description: The time when the task ended.

id.description: The ID of the response phase.

name.description: The name of the response phase.

order.description: The order of the response phase.

create_time.description: The time when this response phase was created, as an epoch timestamp.

update_time.description: The time when this response phase was updated, as an epoch timestamp.

tasks.description: The list of tasks in the response template.

id.description: The ID of the created note.

author.description: The user who created the note.

username.description: The username of Splunk user who added the note.

last_edited_by.description: The email address of the user who edited the note most recently.

incident_id.description: The ID of the incident that contains this note.

files.description: The list of files added to the note.

items.description: The file IDs of the files added to the note

create_time.description: The time when the note was created.

update_time.description: The time when the note was updated.

description.example: Create any necessary tickets or tracking documents describing the initial conditions of the suspicious email investigation. name.description: The name of the task.

order.description: The order of the task in respect to all tasks in the phase.

description.example: Create any necessary tickets or tracking documents describing the initial conditions of the suspicious email investigation. As additional information is collected or actions are taken in the following tasks and phases, update the ticket with links and relevant information to allow collaboration and tracking.

status.description: The status of the task. Available options are Started, Ended, or Reopened.

is_note_required.description: Determines whether a note is required to be created in order to complete or end the task.

TaskSuggestions.description: Playbooks, actions or searches that were added to the task.

actions.description: The list of Splunk SOAR (SOAR) actions added to this response task.

playbooks.description: The list of SOAR playbooks added to this response task.

searches.description: The list of saved searches added to this response task.

id.description: The ID (GUID) of the incident that was retrieved.

display_id.description: The short ID of the incident for display purposes.

name.description: The name of the incident.

create_time.description: The time the incident was created. If the incident was imported from Splunk Enterprise Security, the time matches the notable create time.

mc_create_time.description: The time the incident was created or imported into Splunk Mission Control.

update_time.description: The time the incident was last updated.

incident_origin.description: Where the incident came from. For example, Splunk Enterprise Security, a risk-based alerting notable, or a Splunk Mission Control incident.

source.description: If the incident came from a Splunk Enterprise Security notable, the source is the correlation search that generated the notable.
source.example: Threat - Mission Control - Sample ES Notables - Rule

incident_type.description: The incident type of the incident. Incident types are used to categorize related incidents by use case or source.

notable_id.description: The ID of the Splunk Enterprise Security notable this incident was created from.

disposition.description: The disposition ID of the incident.

disposition_name.description: The classification of the incident. For example, â€œTrue Positive - Suspicious Activityâ€ or â€œFalse Positive - Incorrect Analytic Logicâ€.

response_plans.description: Array of Response Plans added to this incident.

status.description: The status ID of the incident.

status_name.description: The status name of the incident.

assignee.description: The person or group assigned to the incident.

urgency.description: The urgency of the incident. Valid choices are informational, low, medium, high, or critical.

sensitivity.description: The sensitivity of the incident. Valid choices are White, Green, Amber, Red, or Unassigned.

sla.description: The service-level agreement (SLA) of the incident.

sla_condition.description: The condition of the SLA. You can apply different SLA times to incidents that meet particular conditions. If no SLA condition is created, the default condition â€œdefault_slaâ€ is used. To learn more about SLA conditions, see [Manage conditions for an incident SLA](https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/MC/Current/Detect/IncidentSettings#Manage_conditions_for_an_incident_SLA) in *Investigate and Respond to Threats in Splunk Mission Control*.

sla_total_time.description: The total time available to triage or investigate the incident within the SLA.

sla_units.description: Units of time for an SLA. Valid choices are m (minutes), h (hours), or d (days).

sla.description: The time the SLA expires in UTC.

es_notable_fields.description: The fields that are shown on the Incident review page selected from the associated Splunk Enterprise Security notable summary.

attachments.description: Array of file IDs added directly to the incident.

notes.description: Array of note IDs added directly to the incident.

current_response_plan_phase.description: The data surrounding the current response plan phase.

child_incidents.description: The child incidents IDs that have been added to this incident.

field_inheritors.description: The child incident IDs that will inherit this parent incident's owner, status, urgency, sensitivity, and disposition values.

summary.description: The summary fields of the incident. Summary fields appear on the Overview tab.

consolidated_summary.description: The consolidated summary fields of this parent incident and its child incidents. Summary fields appear on the Overview tab.

incident_summary_mapping.description: Mapping of which incident ID the consolidated summary values have originated from.

requestId.description: The request ID of the API call.

create_time.description: When the incident type was created, in Epoch time

update_time.description: When the incident type was last updated, in Epoch time.

response_template_ids.description: IDs of response templates associated with the incident type

SoarApproval.description: SOAR approval with the specific id for the user

Pagination.description: The pagination info of a response

total.description: Total Number of objects returned by the endpoint.

perPage.description: Number of objects to be displayed per page.

id.description: The ID of the Splunk SOAR action.

name.description: The name of the  Splunk SOAR action.

description.example: This action validates the configuration of an asset.

type.description: The type of the  Splunk SOAR action. For example, for a Splunk SOAR app, such as Maxmind, the type could be â€œinvestigateâ€, â€œgenericâ€, â€œtestâ€, â€œcorrectâ€, or â€œcontainâ€.

last_job_id.description: The last job ID of the Splunk SOAR action.

action.description: The action ID of the Splunk SOAR action.

app_id.description: The app ID of the Splunk SOAR action.

asset.description: The asset of the Splunk SOAR action.

parameters.description: The parameters for the Splunk SOAR action. For example, {"ip":"1.1.1.1"}

update_time.description: The time the Splunk SOAR action was updated.

create_time.description: The time the Splunk SOAR action. was created.

id.description: The ID of the Splunk SOAR playbook.

last_job_id.description: The last job ID of the Splunk SOAR playbook.

playbook_id.description: The playbook ID of the Splunk SOAR playbook.

name.description: The name of the Splunk SOAR playbook.

description.description: The description of the Splunk SOAR playbook.

scope.description: The scope of the Splunk SOAR playbook. For example, â€œall" or â€œnew".

update_time.description: The update time of the SOAR playbook.

create_time.description: The create time of the SOAR playbook.

id.description: The ID of the search.

name.description: The name of the saved search.
name.example: Access - Access Over Time By App

spl.description: The SPL query for the saved search.

description.description: The description of the saved search.
description.example: Use Splunk searches to list the stats for app accessing

update_time.description: The update time of the saved search.

create_time.description: The create time of the saved search.

title.description: The title of the response plan note.

content.description: The data stored within the note.

files.description: An array of file IDs to add to a note.

FileObject.description: Information on files stored in Mission Control

id.description: The unique ID for this file.

incident_type.description: The incident type of the incident. Incident types are used to categorize related incidents by use case or source.

incident_id.description: The incident ID of the object that attached this file.

id.description: The response plan ID if this was a file uploaded from a response task.

name.description: The name of the response plan.

id.description: The response phase ID if this was a file uploaded from a response task.

name.description: The name of the response phase.

id.description: The response task ID if this was a file uploaded from a response task.

name.description: The name of the response task.

reference_list.description: A list of object IDs (response note, task, etc.) that uploaded this file.

size.description: The size of the file in bytes.

source_type.description: The type of object that added this file.

source.description: The ID of the object (response note, task, etc.) that added this file.

source_user.description: The username of the user that added this file.

created_on.description: The time when this file was initially added.

file_key.description: The sha256 hash of the contents of this file.

_user.description: User field generated by Splunk and added to the KV Store.
